i have everything on my own site for free, because it seems like a friendly thing to do. but many people are not used to getting music that way, so as an alternative i sell it on itunes, etc. but that's really just a charade for people who are accustomed to thinking you have to buy music. if i didn't sell it there, people would be asking me where they can get it. so i figure rather than spend time explaining how i'm offering it for free, i figure i will just offer it both ways, and everyone will find it in a way that they are comfortable with.

I'm a poet and wonder if song is the next form of my art. I have little skill in music; words are my clay, and I can sculpt them to any shape I desire...but what is the link between the beauty of words and the resplendence of music?

there are many different ways of doing all this, but in my experience, the music picks up a lot of the slack. most great songs look very short on paper (if you just look at the lyrics), and also look very nothing. most times when people write things that are meant to stand on their own without music, and then try to put to music, there is usually way too much content to fit in a song, and often there are many words that look good on paper but just aren't very singable. then again, this can be done many many different ways. the only way i know is to do it all at the same time. i think songwriting might be more similar to writing a script for a movie than poetry.

ok i've got first verse, chorus, second verse, second chorus. now what?

take a deep breath, and run through the song. the song already has a strong identity. ask the song what it needs, if anything. to do this right, you need to keep cleaering your head and running the song from the beginning, and right as you are getting to the end of the second chorus, that's when you will have the clearest idea of what needs to happen. Remember to remain open to all possibilities! including nothing. this part of songwriting is something i call "finishing" because there is really no telling what it's going to need. every song is different. i've heard so many songs that in my opinion fail at 'finishing' because they didn't take proper care to figure out what's best for that song. in other words, having a bridge when there shouldn't be a bridge. having the wrong kind of bridge. bridges are unpredictable anyway and this ties in with the 'be open to anything' strategy. this is a very sensitive part of the process, and every song needs something distinctly different, and quite possibly nothing. you will only know clearly after doing a full run through, and start paying attention about halfway through second chorus. many times your next step will be something that almost interrupts the end of the chorus to go to a different thing. other examples of things that work in some songs are: another verse with no lyrics. another chorus with no lyrics. maybe a totally different thing with no lyrics. another chorus with different lyrics. a totally different thing with lyrics. but this is a sensitive issue and every song has very distinctive needs, so you need to make sure you are doing full run throughs and really let the song decide what it needs or doesn't need.

hey not to like tell you how to do your website, cause it's yours and people bother you about that all the time, but i just thought you'd like to know that if you embedded your videos from youtube instead of uploading them to your site they'd load faster. i think they would run slower if i did that. also it is extremely important that it runs without glitches once it loads, and also to be able to have quick access to any point in the video, easy pause/unpause, etc. all those things are made extremely difficult on youtube. also, easy downloadability is something i value above all else. the ultimate viewing experience is watching it on your hard drive, in my opinion. that's why it is extremely important to me to provide that experience for people. that's what this site is for- i'm giving you all this content. for those who prefer the youtube experience, they can watch on youtube. and for the shorter ones i would recommend vine

What font do you use.. Helvetica? and why?

i used to worry about different fonts for everything, but that became not only a waste of time, but also distracting from a viewing standpoint. i ultimately made a decision to actually use the default font for everything. it gave me a lot of creative clarity, and greater efficiency. i learned it's better to focus on your strong points, and don't worry about things that are not your strong points. i don't make my own fonts, and i don't have access to a large font libary, so this would not be a strong point. by religiously using the default font only, i found that i could instantly put all my focus on things that are my strong points -- positioning, angles, motion, and timing.

i know you work alone, I get that. but have you ever tried creating with another person? The biggest advantage I take out of this is because it is more fun, to laugh with another one. keep up the good work! love you

trust me, the only reason i work alone is because i have to. i spent years and years thinking you were "supposed" to collaborate, and that i was just messed up for not being able to make it work. i knew i "could" do it alone, but i thought it was frowned upon. and i knew it would certainly be more enjoyable and less lonely to work together with someone. but i very rarely found anyone i could work with, and i tried many many times to collaborate and failed miserably. i just always wanted to take it to mars way too quickly. no one would really take me seriously. while the whole time i thought i was the one being serious. finally i saw an interview with a very successful songwriter about collaboration, and he said "i actually don't collaborate well. one of the reasons i like songwriting is because it's something you can actually do all by yourself." that's when i finally stopped feeling guilty about it, and that's when the real work started. ever since then everything has been going fine, although i am still lonely

hey Bill,have you got a name for that classic soul progression that goes VI-V-Im-VIIm-III-VI-V -Im? Like "just the two of us" or "if you want me to stay" (but in this case already beggining in the root), and have you ever heard any nice twists to it?Keep up the good work! Love you

i don't have a name for it, other than to say it's the good old "5min to set up the 4" except it's used from the perspective of the relative minor. so like, if you're in a minor key, it's when you go ahead and smack the flat7min7, to set up the b6.  honestly, a pretty slick version of this which you might get a kick out of, is in the verse of 'let me love you one more time' (benson). and then there's obviously biggie's 'big poppa' which i believe is actually just isley brothers. also check out the second verse of a song called "You" by mya, on the word "grow." this one has the extra passing tone thrown in for bonus points. Also, another twist i just thought of -- a lot of songs do like a 2-5 and then another 2-5 a whole step lower -- so it actually kind of has that same effect when it hits the 2 of the second 2-5-- sounds like the b7min7. example of that would be c'est la vie by robbie neville. 'love' by musiq does another one chromatically in the verse, but the melody doesn't obey it as well as the 'mya' example.  here's one that may seem subtle -- there was a mariah carey song (maybe 2006??) called 'shake it off" it's really just 3 chord hits, but it implies the same thing. t-pain 'show you how' also uses it pretty quick. also 'luv' by janet jackson uses it very expertly, with a gold-plated tritone substitution thing for the inbetween chord. basically all these are the b7min7 (to usually set up the b6) from a minor key. hope that's what you meant, i'm just taking that as the main common thread between your examples. ultimately this is a good technique, which i bet not many people know nowadays, and it is surely a great way to get chicks

how do you deal with the: oh, this chord feels nice. oh, this one feels better. oh, this one is actually better than the two before. oh, this one is kinda in between, etc. whenever I'm making a song I can't help but think whether the chords I used were the best. Have you ever felt like this?

Do you have issues with focus when working on a specific project? If so, how do you reign yourself back in when it's not very interesting at that moment to work on?

this is an 'angel's voice, tapping you on the shoulder and saying 'are you sure this is the right project?' so you lay around for a few hours and contemplate the question. and if you are sure it is, then that's the go ahead. if you still feel things are moving slowly, then go to a microscopic next-step approach. also perhaps you are a bit off track in this section of the project. consider tightening up or drastically simplifying that particular part of the project. that will often clear things right up, and get you right back to focusing on your original reasons for doing the whole thing in the first place. it's like a tree. you are way out on the branches. get back to the trunk, that branch ur on might not even matter

but how do you find the right thing? just listen? but that's so hard to do when everyone around you is so loud and tries to tell you their own ideas of what the right thing is, and it's even harder when your thing doesn't exist yet

it can be stressful when everyone is re-enforcing the same old ideas. but the fact that you have the feeling of wanting to break away is proof of existence. photo-copy that and stamp it as proof that you are real. then just start building upon that. set up some free space where you are free to brainstorm ideas and save them. your situation sounds very familiar to me, and i would be glad to give you more tips.  please get in touch if you need to, my email is on the email page

How did you help yourself break out of the 'norm' and go into the uncharted part of the human life? You seem to have realized a special attitude towards the tried and tested very young in your life and would love to know what factors helped you be brave enough to live up to the ideology.

the fact that i never really fit in pushed me that way. i spent a lot of time learning music (only on instruments) at a very young age, and avoiding anything 'popular.' then sometime when i was a teenager i just snapped and said wait a minute, what's popular? more specifically, where is the real cutting edge? i was a little disappointed to realize that most of what's popular is usually actually not the cutting edge ... but i began searching for the cutting edge, whatever that should be. and i sort of tumbled into a huge search, which finally cumulated in the realization that because infinite universes do and can exist, they have to all be right. and that exploded into some heavy ideas about what this all means and why we're here. i've spent my entire life since then trying to figure out how to explain that. what makes that challenging is the fact that the only way to actually explain it is to prove that it has already been explained
